title: Capstone Finalization — Creating a Bibliography and Author's Note
description: Students finalize their capstone research reports by creating a polished bibliography and writing an author's note explaining their personal connection to the topic. They learn about academic honesty and the tradition of acknowledging sources and sharing their journey as researchers.
instructions:
1. 'Your report is nearly complete! Today we add two important final pieces: the bibliography and the author's note.'
2. Review the bibliography from last week's draft. Refine the format: Author Last Name, First Name. Title of Book. Publisher, Year.
3. For any websites used: Website Name. 'Article Title.' URL.
4. Arrange sources in alphabetical order by author's last name.
5. Write an author's note: 'This is where YOU speak directly to the reader. Why did you choose this topic? What surprised you during your research? What was the hardest part? What do you hope readers learn?'
6. Model with an example author's note.
7. Child writes their own author's note (aim for 1 paragraph, about 5-8 sentences).
8. Add both pages to the report.
9. Final review: read the complete report from cover to cover.

slides.heading: Finishing Touches
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a really important book! It tells us that we're getting ready to put the finishing touches on our big research reports, and we'll be adding two special parts: a bibliography and an author's note.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a bibliography format reference card showing the correct format for books and websites. Gather all source materials so the child can verify author names, titles, and publication years.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these things! We have your report that you've been working so hard on, a little card that shows us exactly how to write down our sources, some nice lined paper, all the books and websites you used for your research, and a pencil. This is everything we need to make our report super official and professional!

slides.text: Explain the bibliography's importance: 'Every serious researcher gives credit to the people whose work helped them. A bibliography lists all the books, articles, and sources you used. It shows you are honest and thorough.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us about giving credit where it's due. Just like when you borrow a toy from a friend, it's important to say where you got your information from. A bibliography is like a thank-you list for all the books and websites that helped you learn, and it shows you're an honest super-researcher!

slides.text: Format the entries: 'For each book: Author's last name, first name. Title of the book (underlined or in italics). Publisher name, year. Arrange all entries in alphabetical order by the author's last name.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to learn the secret code for writing down our sources so they look super neat and tidy. For books, we'll write the author's last name, then their first name, then the book's title, and finally where it was published and when, and we'll put all these lists in ABC order!

slides.text: Introduce the author's note: 'Many books include a note from the author explaining why they wrote it. YOUR author's note tells the reader: Why did you choose this topic? What surprised you? What was challenging? What do you hope people learn?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next part is really exciting because it's all about YOU! The author's note is your chance to talk right to the person reading your report and tell them why you picked your topic, what cool things you discovered that maybe surprised you, what was a little tricky to figure out, and what you hope they learn from your amazing work.

slides.text: Model it: 'Here is an example: I chose to write about Ancient Egypt because I was fascinated by the pyramids. I was surprised to learn that the workers were not slaves but skilled craftsmen. The hardest part was understanding the hieroglyphic system. I hope readers discover how amazing Egyptian civilization was.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this example? The person writing it explains they love pyramids, they were surprised to learn that pyramid builders weren't slaves, and that learning hieroglyphics was tough but they hope you think Egypt is awesome too. Your author's note will be just like this, but with your own unique story!

slides.prompt: Create your polished bibliography with at least 3 sources in proper format, arranged alphabetically. Then write your author's note (5-8 sentences) explaining your personal connection to the topic, surprises from your research, challenges you faced, and what you hope readers will learn.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to shine! It's time to create your bibliography by writing down all your sources in the right order, and then write your own author's note. Tell us why you chose your topic, what surprised you, what was hard, and what you want readers to take away from your report. You've got this!

slides.text: Read the complete report from start to finish: 'From the title page to the bibliography — this is a complete, professional research report. You should feel enormously proud. You are a published author and researcher!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child format a bibliography with proper citations, write a reflective author's note, and assemble a complete multi-component research report?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your finished report! You've done it all – from the beginning all the way to the bibliography and your own author's note. You’ve shown everyone that you’re a real researcher and author, and you should be so incredibly proud of all your hard work!

parent_notes: The bibliography teaches academic honesty at its most fundamental level — giving credit where it is due. This concept, introduced early, builds a foundation for academic integrity throughout the child's education. The format does not need to be perfect APA or MLA; the important thing is that the child understands WHY we cite sources and can list them in an organized way. The author's note is a metacognitive exercise: the child reflects on their own learning process, identifying what engaged them, what challenged them, and what they discovered. This self-awareness about learning is a hallmark of mature thinkers. Reading the complete report from start to finish gives the child the experience of holding their finished work — a powerful moment of accomplishment. This report represents weeks of sustained effort across multiple skill domains. Celebrate it accordingly. In Montessori terms, this is the child's great work — a meaningful project completed with independence, purpose, and pride.

title: Math Review Stations — Operations and Problem Solving
description: Students rotate through review stations focusing on the four operations: addition with carrying, subtraction with borrowing, multi-digit multiplication, and long division. Each station includes word problems that apply operations to real-world contexts, celebrating how far the child has come.
instructions:
1. 'This week we celebrate everything you have learned in math! Today we start with the four operations — the foundations of all mathematics.'
2. Set up 4 stations, each with 15-minute activities:
   - Station 1: Addition — multi-digit addition with carrying, word problems involving distances, populations, and money.
   - Station 2: Subtraction — multi-digit subtraction with borrowing, word problems involving differences, change, and elapsed time.
   - Station 3: Multiplication — 2-digit by 1-digit and 2-digit by 2-digit, word problems involving groups, arrays, and area.
   - Station 4: Division — long division with single-digit divisors, word problems involving sharing, grouping, and rates.
3. At each station, complete 3-4 problems independently.
4. Check answers with a calculator after completing each station.
5. Track mastery: star the problems you found easy, circle the ones that were challenging.
6. 'You can do ALL of these! Look at how much you have grown this year!'
materials_needed: Station cards with problems for each operation
Golden bead material or base-ten blocks (optional)
Star and circle stickers for self-assessment

slides.heading: Operation Stations
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our exciting math adventure today! It's called "Operation Stations," and it means we're going to practice all the important math steps, like adding and subtracting, which are the building blocks for everything else in math. Get ready to show off how much you know!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 4 distinct stations around the room. Each station needs: 4 computation problems of increasing difficulty, 2 word problems, scratch paper, and a calculator (face-down, for checking only). Prepare problems at the child's current level with slight stretch challenges.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll use for our math stations today. We have problem cards with the math questions, scratch paper to do our work, a calculator to check our answers *after* we try them, and a timer to keep us on track. There are also special stickers to show how well you did! You'll need to gather these materials to get started at each station.

slides.text: Set the tone: 'This is not a test — this is a CELEBRATION of your mathematical growth! At the beginning of the year, some of these problems would have been impossible. Now you can do them all. Let us prove it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for how we'll start our math stations. The slide is telling us to remember that this isn't a test to trick you; it's a chance to celebrate all the amazing math skills you've learned this year! Think about how tricky some of these problems might have seemed before, and now you're going to solve them like a pro!

slides.text: Station 1 — Addition: 'Start with the addition station. You will find multi-digit addition problems and word problems. Show your work, use carrying when needed, and check with the calculator when you finish.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our first stop: Station 1, where we'll work on addition! You'll see problems where you might need to carry numbers over to the next column, and you'll also solve word problems about things like how far people travel or how much money things cost. Do your best on the problems, and then use the calculator to check your work when you're done.

slides.text: Station 2 — Subtraction: 'Move to subtraction. Remember borrowing! When the top digit is smaller than the bottom digit, borrow from the next column. Word problems will ask about differences and change.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up is Station 2, all about subtraction! Remember when we learned about borrowing? That's going to be key here, especially when the top number in a column is smaller than the bottom number. The word problems at this station will be about finding differences or figuring out how much time has passed.

slides.text: Stations 3 and 4 — Multiplication and Division: 'Multiplication uses repeated addition and the algorithm you learned. Division is the reverse — sharing into equal groups. Show all your work and check with the calculator.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're heading to Stations 3 and 4, which are for multiplication and division. Multiplication is like adding the same number over and over, and division is like sharing things fairly into equal groups. For both, you'll write out all your steps to show how you figured out the answer, and then you'll use the calculator to double-check your math.

slides.prompt: Complete all 4 stations. At each one, solve at least 4 computation problems and 2 word problems. Show all your work. After each station, check with the calculator and mark: star for problems you found easy, circle for ones that challenged you.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling you exactly what to do at each station! You'll solve a few problems at each of the four stations, making sure to show all your work on the scratch paper. After you finish all the problems at a station, use the calculator to check your answers. Then, give yourself a star for the problems that felt easy and circle the ones that were a little tricky – that helps us see what we're super good at and what we can practice more!

slides.text: Review the self-assessment: 'Look at all those stars! And the circles show you where you can keep growing. Every mathematician has areas of strength and areas for growth. The important thing is that you tackled ALL of them with confidence!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform multi-digit addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division with accuracy, apply operations to word problems, and self-assess their mathematical strengths?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the stars you earned! This last slide is celebrating your success. The stars show the math skills you've mastered, and the circles show where you can keep practicing to get even stronger. Every great mathematician knows they have things they're brilliant at and things they're still learning, and you tackled everything today with confidence!

parent_notes: Review stations are far more effective than traditional tests because they are low-pressure, self-paced, and include built-in self-assessment. The star/circle system teaches metacognition — the ability to evaluate one's own understanding. Celebrate the stars enthusiastically and treat the circles as valuable information, not failures. If you notice patterns in the circles (always struggles with borrowing in subtraction, for example), note them for summer practice. The calculator is used only for checking, not solving — this builds both computational skills and verification habits. The word problems are especially important because they test whether the child can identify which operation to use, not just execute the algorithm. If the child flies through all stations, add challenge problems (larger numbers, multi-step word problems). This is a celebration of growth, so compare current performance to the beginning of the year. The growth will be astonishing.

title: Capstone Timeline — Connecting All Historical Periods
description: Students create a comprehensive personal timeline connecting every historical period studied throughout the year. This capstone history project synthesizes the entire curriculum into a single visual narrative, revealing the grand arc of human civilization.
instructions:
1. 'All year we have studied history one period at a time. Today we connect them ALL into one magnificent timeline — the story of human civilization!'
2. Provide a long roll of paper (or tape several sheets together) for the timeline.
3. List all periods studied: Big Bang, Timeline of Life, First Humans, Mesopotamia, Egypt, Indus Valley, China, Greece, Rome, Middle Ages, Renaissance, Scientific Revolution, Enlightenment, Industrial Revolution, American/French Revolutions, 19th Century, WWI, WWII, Civil Rights, Modern World.
4. For each period, the child writes the name, approximate dates, and draws one key image or symbol.
5. Add connecting annotations: 'How did one period lead to the next? What ideas or events caused change?'
6. Include the child's favorite fact or person from each period.
7. At the end of the timeline, add 'The Future' with the child's predictions or hopes.
8. This timeline will be displayed at the week 35 history museum.
materials_needed: Long roll of paper or taped-together sheets (at least 6 feet)
Reference list of all periods and dates studied

slides.heading: My History Timeline
slides.subheading: The Grand Story of Human Civilization
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our super big project! It's showing us that we're going to make a timeline that tells the whole, giant story of everything that's ever happened, from the very, very beginning all the way up to right now. It's called "The Grand Story of Human Civilization" because it covers all of us and how we got to be here today!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a long timeline base — tape multiple sheets of paper together or use a paper roll. Create a reference list of all historical periods studied with approximate dates. Gather the child's previous history work for reference and inspiration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for our amazing timeline! We've got a super long roll of paper – this is going to be the path for our whole history story. We also have colorful pencils and markers so we can make our timeline exciting to look at, and a ruler to help us draw straight lines. You'll also need your old history papers because they have all the cool facts and information we'll use. Don't forget to grab some tape to stick everything together!

slides.text: Set the vision: 'Imagine unrolling the entire story of human civilization on one long paper. From the very beginning — the Big Bang — all the way to today and beyond. That is what we are creating right now!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about getting our minds ready for the awesome journey we're about to take! Imagine stretching out the whole story of time, from the very first moment anything existed, all the way to what's happening right now. We're going to put all those important moments onto our long paper, making one giant, connected story of how humans and the world have changed. Isn't it exciting to think we're going to build that whole story?

slides.text: Start the framework: 'Draw a long line down the center of the paper. On the left end, write the Big Bang and the beginning of the universe. On the right end, write TODAY and THE FUTURE. Now we fill in everything in between.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to draw the basic road for our history story! Take your ruler and draw one long line going straight down the middle of your big paper. On the very left side, where the line starts, we'll write "The Big Bang" because that's the beginning of everything in the universe. Then, on the far right side, where the line ends, we'll write "TODAY" and "THE FUTURE" because that's where we are now. Everything else we learned this year will fit right in between that line!

slides.text: Fill in the periods: 'For each civilization and era we studied, write the name and dates, draw a small symbol or picture, and write your favorite fact. Connect them with the timeline line. Use different colors for different eras.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start filling in all the amazing places and times we learned about! For every history period we studied, like ancient Egypt or the time of the dinosaurs, you'll write its name and when it happened on the timeline. Then, draw a little picture that reminds you of that time, and write down your very favorite fact or person from it. Remember to connect each one to that long line you drew so it all flows together, and use different colors to make it pop!

slides.text: Add connections: 'History is not just a list of events — it is a STORY of cause and effect. Write brief notes connecting periods: Greek ideas influenced Rome. The printing press led to the Scientific Revolution. Draw arrows showing these connections.'
slides.mascot_explanation: History isn't just a bunch of stuff that happened; it's like a big chain reaction! This step is about showing how one thing led to another, like how one event made something else happen. You'll write little notes or draw arrows to show how, for example, ideas from ancient Greece might have helped the Romans, or how a new invention helped science grow. It's like showing how the past whispers secrets to the future!

slides.prompt: Create your comprehensive timeline with ALL historical periods studied this year. Each entry needs: name, approximate dates, one drawing/symbol, and one favorite fact. Add at least 5 connection arrows showing how one period led to another. End with 'The Future' and your predictions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to create your masterpiece! You've got all your materials, and you know all the steps. Just take your time and fill in every single history period we learned about, adding the name, dates, a cool picture, and your favorite fact for each. Make sure to draw at least five "connection arrows" showing how different times are linked together, and don't forget to add your own ideas about "The Future" at the very end. You've got this!

slides.text: Step back and admire: 'Look at what you have created — the entire story of human civilization on one timeline! YOU know this story now. From the first civilizations to the modern world, you understand how we got here. This knowledge is part of you forever.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child place all major historical periods in chronological order, provide key facts for each, identify cause-and-effect connections between periods, and articulate the continuity of human history?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that incredible timeline you've built! You've just put the *entire* story of human history right there on your paper, from the very beginning to today. You now know how all those different times and places connect and how we got to where we are. This amazing story is now a part of your own knowledge, and you can remember it always!

parent_notes: This comprehensive timeline is the capstone of the year's history curriculum and a powerful demonstration of the child's knowledge. The physical act of placing all periods on one continuous line reveals the grand narrative that individual lessons can obscure. Expect the child to have strong memories of some periods and vague recollections of others — that is completely normal. The periods they remember best are the ones that captured their imagination, and those details will stay with them. The connection arrows are the most intellectually demanding part: identifying cause-and-effect across historical periods requires sophisticated analytical thinking. Help with prompts if needed ('Why did the Renaissance happen? What came before it that made people want to rediscover learning?'). The 'Future' section at the end is inspiring — the child sees themselves as part of an ongoing story, not just observers of the past. Display this timeline proudly at the week 35 history museum. It is a magnificent achievement.

title: Capstone Atlas Page — My Favorite Country or Region
description: Students create a detailed atlas page for their favorite country or region studied during the year. The page includes a map, geographic features, climate, culture, economy, and personal reflections, synthesizing the year's geographic knowledge into one focused masterpiece.
instructions:
1. 'All year we have explored the world — every continent, dozens of countries, countless geographic features. Now you create your own atlas page for YOUR favorite place!'
2. Child selects their favorite country or region from the year's studies.
3. Atlas page components:
   - Detailed map with borders, capital, major cities, rivers, and mountains.
   - Physical features: landforms, bodies of water, climate zones.
   - Flag and brief history.
   - Culture: language, food, traditions, art.
   - Economy: what the country produces or is known for.
   - Fun facts: at least 5 interesting details.
   - Personal note: 'Why I chose this place and what I would do if I visited.'
4. Use reference maps and books for accuracy.
5. Make it beautiful — this is a page worthy of a real atlas!
6. This page will be shared during the week 35 'World Tour' presentation.
materials_needed: Large paper or card stock for atlas page

slides.heading: My Atlas Page
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of your amazing project! It shows us that you're about to create your very own atlas page, which is like a special book page all about a place you love. Get ready to make something super cool about geography!

slides.setup_instructions: Provide the child with a large, clean sheet of paper or card stock. Gather reference materials specific to their chosen country. Have a globe or world map available for spatial context.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these tools we get to use for our project! We have big paper for our masterpiece, reference maps and atlases to help us draw accurately, and colorful pencils and markers to make it look awesome. There's also a ruler for straight lines and reference books for all the cool facts we need to find. Don't forget the globe – it helps us see where our country is in the whole world! Go grab everything with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: Choose your place: 'Think about all the countries and regions we explored this year. Which one fascinated you most? Which one do you dream of visiting? THAT is the one you will create an atlas page for.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is the very first step to making your atlas page super special. Think about all the amazing places we learned about this year – like countries with yummy food, cool traditions, or incredible animals! Which one made you say "Wow!" the most? Pick that place, because it's going to be the star of your atlas page.

slides.text: Start with the map: 'Draw the outline of your country carefully — use a reference map to get the shape right. Mark the capital with a star, major cities with dots, rivers with blue lines, and mountains with small triangles. Add a compass rose.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to draw the map for your chosen place! Grab a reference map so you can get the shape just right, like you're tracing it. You'll put a star for the capital city, little dots for other big cities, blue lines for rivers, and tiny triangles for mountains. Oh, and don't forget to add a compass rose so everyone knows which way is north!

slides.text: Add layers of information: 'A great atlas page has more than just a map. Add sections for: Physical Features (landforms, climate), Culture (language, food, traditions), Economy (what the country produces), and Fun Facts (at least 5 interesting details).'
slides.mascot_explanation: A great atlas page is like a treasure chest full of information! Besides the map, you need to add other cool stuff. We'll create spots for physical features like mountains and deserts, talk about the culture like food and holidays, share what the country is known for making or doing (that's the economy!), and add at least five super interesting fun facts.

slides.text: Make it personal: 'Real atlases give facts. YOUR atlas page also includes YOUR voice. Write a section called My Connection: why you chose this place, what you find most fascinating, and what you would do if you visited.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about YOU! Real atlases have facts, but your page will have your own special thoughts. You'll write a little note called "My Connection" where you share why you picked this place and what amazing things you'd love to do there if you could visit. It's like telling everyone your travel dreams!

slides.prompt: Create a complete atlas page for your chosen country or region. Include: a detailed map with labels, physical features section, culture section, economy section, at least 5 fun facts, the national flag, and a personal connection paragraph. Make it visually beautiful!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put all those pieces together and create your masterpiece! Use your map, all the information you found about culture and fun facts, and your personal note to make this atlas page look incredible. Remember to add the flag, and make it as colorful and beautiful as you can – you have about 28 minutes to make it shine!

slides.text: Admire the work: 'This atlas page is worthy of a real published atlas! You combined cartography, geography, cultural knowledge, research skills, and artistic talent into one beautiful page. Next week you will share it with everyone during the World Tour.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create an accurate, detailed, and visually appealing atlas page that integrates geographic, cultural, and economic information about a chosen country?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing atlas page! You did it! You combined maps, facts, and your own ideas to create something truly special, just like in a real atlas. You learned so much about geography and put it all onto one awesome page. Get ready, because next week you'll get to share your incredible work with everyone on our 'World Tour'!

parent_notes: The atlas page is a perfect capstone geography project because it requires the integration of every geographic skill learned this year: map drawing, physical geography, cultural knowledge, economic understanding, and spatial reasoning. The personal element — choosing their favorite place and explaining why — honors the child's individual interests and makes the work meaningful rather than merely academic. Accuracy matters but so does beauty: atlases are both informative and artistic. Encourage the child to take their time with the map drawing, using reference materials for accuracy. The personal connection paragraph reveals what aspects of geography captured the child's imagination — landscapes, cultures, foods, history, or wildlife. All are valid entry points. This page will be presented during week 35's World Tour, so it should be the child's best work. Consider laminating it afterward as a keepsake of this year's geographic journey.

title: Read-Aloud: Rosie Revere — Perseverance and the Courage to Fail
description: This story about a girl who learns that failure is not the end but a step toward success connects to the week's themes of perseverance, capstone projects, and celebrating the courage to try. It reinforces the growth mindset essential for the transition to upper elementary.
instructions:
1. 'This book is about a girl named Rosie who loves to invent things. But she has a problem — she is afraid of failing. Does that ever happen to you?'
2. Read the story with expression, pausing at key moments.
3. When Rosie hides her inventions: 'Why does she stop inventing? Have you ever stopped doing something because you were afraid it was not good enough?'
4. When Great-Great-Aunt Rose laughs (with joy, not at Rosie): 'What changed for Rosie in this moment?'
5. Discuss the key message: 'The only true failure is quitting. Every flop is a step toward success.'
6. Connect to the capstone projects: 'This week you are finishing big projects. Were there moments that were hard? Moments you wanted to give up? You did not — you persevered!'
7. Write about a time you persevered through something difficult this year.
materials_needed: Rosie Revere, Engineer by Andrea Beaty

slides.heading: Rosie Revere, Engineer
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the cover of our book, "Rosie Revere, Engineer"! It's all about a super smart girl who loves to build things, but the subtitle tells us something important: "The Power of Perseverance." That means we're going to learn how important it is to keep trying, even when things get tough.

items: Rosie Revere, Engineer by Andrea Beaty
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If unavailable, substitute with The Most Magnificent Thing by Ashley Spires or Beautiful Oops! by Barney Saltzberg. Prepare response paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things to get started. We need the book "Rosie Revere, Engineer," some paper for writing your thoughts, and colored pencils for drawing. If we don't have that exact book, there are other super cool stories that teach us the same lesson about trying your best.

slides.text: Introduce the theme: 'As you finish your capstone projects this week, there is something important to remember about the journey. This story is about Rosie, a brilliant inventor who almost gave up. But listen to what she learned...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to start our story! The teacher is going to tell us about Rosie, who is a really good inventor. But sometimes, even when you're good at something, it can be hard, and you might want to stop. This story is going to show us why it's important to remember how to keep going, especially since you're all working on your big projects!

slides.text: Read and pause. When Rosie hides her inventions after being laughed at: 'Rosie is afraid. She stops creating. Have you ever been afraid to try something because you might fail? What happens when we let that fear stop us?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen closely as we read about Rosie. When she gets upset and hides her inventions, think about why she's doing that. Have you ever felt like hiding something you made because you were worried it wasn't perfect? It's okay to feel that way, but let's see what happens next.

slides.text: At the turning point: 'Great-Great-Aunt Rose does not laugh AT Rosie — she laughs with joy because Rosie TRIED. She says the only true failure is not trying at all. What do you think about that?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, did you hear that? Rosie's Great-Great-Aunt Rose didn't laugh *at* Rosie, she laughed *with* her because Rosie was brave enough to try something new! Rosie learned that the biggest mistake isn't messing up, but it's giving up completely. Doesn't that make you think about trying new things?

slides.text: Connect to life: 'This year you have done many hard things — challenging math, research writing, science experiments, new ideas. There were probably moments you wanted to quit. But you kept going. That is the message of this book: keep going!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about all the amazing things you've learned and done this school year. Remember those tricky math problems or when you were writing a long story? Sometimes it felt hard, and maybe you wanted to stop, but you didn't! You kept going, and that's exactly what this book is teaching us – the power of never giving up.

slides.prompt: Write about a time this year when something was really hard but you kept going. What was the challenge? How did you feel in the middle? What happened because you persevered? Draw a picture of yourself overcoming the challenge.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show how awesome you are at persevering! On your paper, write about a time this year when something was really, really hard for you. Think about how you felt when it was tough, but then how you kept trying anyway. After you write, draw a picture of yourself being super strong and finishing that challenge!

slides.text: Affirm: 'Every single person who accomplished something amazing — every scientist, artist, mathematician, historian — failed many times along the way. The difference is they kept trying. You have that same spirit. Carry it with you always.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the book's message about perseverance, connect it to personal experiences, and articulate the value of persistence through difficulty?
slides.mascot_explanation: You all did such a fantastic job listening and thinking about Rosie's story! Just like Rosie, and all the amazing inventors and artists in the world, you have the power to keep trying even when things are hard. Remember that spirit of perseverance as you keep learning and growing every single day!

parent_notes: Rosie Revere, Engineer is a perfect bridge between the capstone project work and the approaching transition to upper elementary. As the child finishes major projects, they can reflect on the challenges they overcame along the way. The growth mindset message — that failure is learning, not defeat — is one of the most important concepts a child can internalize before the more demanding work of upper elementary. The written response about personal perseverance creates a powerful self-portrait of resilience. Share your own stories of persevering through difficulty — children need to know that adults face challenges too. Andrea Beaty's other books (Ada Twist, Scientist and Iggy Peck, Architect) make excellent companion reads if your child enjoys this one. The key takeaway: intelligence and talent matter, but perseverance matters more.

title: Presentation Skills Workshop — Speaking with Confidence
description: Students practice essential presentation skills: clear voice projection, eye contact, body language, pacing, and responding to questions. They rehearse presenting their capstone report and receive constructive feedback to build public speaking confidence.
instructions:
1. 'Next week you will present your research to your family. Today we practice the skills that make presentations powerful!'
2. Teach the 5 keys to great presenting:
   - Volume: speak loudly enough for everyone to hear.
   - Eye contact: look at your audience, not just your paper.
   - Posture: stand tall and still, with your shoulders back.
   - Pacing: speak slowly enough to be understood. Pause between ideas.
   - Enthusiasm: let your audience feel your excitement about the topic.
3. Practice each skill separately with fun exercises:
   - Volume: say a sentence at whisper, normal, and presentation volume.
   - Eye contact: present one fact while looking at 3 different spots in the room.
   - Pacing: present a paragraph fast, then at the perfect speed.
4. Full rehearsal: present the capstone report using all 5 skills.
5. Give specific, kind feedback after each practice.
6. Practice answering questions: 'What if someone asks you a question about your topic?'
materials_needed: Stuffed animals or family photos as 'audience'

slides.heading: Presenting with Power
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide has a big, exciting title: "Presenting with Power!" It's telling us that today we're going to learn how to be super-duper speakers, like superheroes of talking! We're going to learn all the tricks to make our voices strong and our presentations amazing.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a presentation area with a 'stage' and 'audience' space. Place stuffed animals or family photos in audience seats if no live audience is available. Prepare a presentation skills checklist: Volume, Eye Contact, Posture, Pacing, Enthusiasm.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our presentation practice! We've got your awesome capstone report, a special checklist to help us remember our skills, and a timer to keep us on track. We'll also set up a pretend stage and have some audience members, like stuffed animals or even your family, to practice talking to. It’s like setting up a mini-theater for our big show!

slides.text: Set the stage: 'Great researchers do not just write their findings — they PRESENT them. Scientists give talks. Authors do readings. Historians give lectures. Today you learn the skills that make a presentation unforgettable.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step tells us why practicing is so important! Just like scientists share their discoveries and authors share their stories, you get to share your super cool research. Think of it like this: presenting is your chance to show everyone how much you know and how exciting your topic is, making your report truly unforgettable.

slides.text: Teach the five keys: 'Key 1: Volume — be heard by the person farthest away. Key 2: Eye Contact — look at your audience, not your paper. Key 3: Posture — stand tall and confident. Key 4: Pacing — speak slowly enough to be understood. Key 5: Enthusiasm — show your audience you love this topic!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning the five secret powers for amazing presentations! First, we need *Volume* so everyone can hear us, even the person way in the back. Then, *Eye Contact* means looking at our audience to connect with them, not just reading. *Posture* is standing tall and proud, like a confident explorer. *Pacing* is talking just right, not too fast, so everyone can understand. And finally, *Enthusiasm* is showing how excited you are about your topic – that's contagious!

slides.text: Practice each skill: 'Let us try volume first. Say this sentence at a whisper... now at your normal voice... now at presentation volume. Good! Now, tell me one fact from your report while looking at my eyes, then the wall, then back to me.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the fun practice begins! We're going to try out those five powers. We’ll practice saying a sentence super quietly, then normally, and finally, with a big, strong presentation voice. Then, you'll share a fact from your report while looking at different spots, just like you'll do for your audience. It’s like training your speaking muscles!

slides.text: Full rehearsal: 'Now present your report using ALL five skills. I will be your audience. Afterward, I will tell you what you did brilliantly and one thing to polish. Then we will try again!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the main event – the full practice! You're going to present your whole report, using all five of those powerful skills we just learned: volume, eye contact, posture, pacing, and enthusiasm. I'll be your audience and listen carefully, then I'll tell you all the amazing things you did and one little thing we can make even better. Then we'll do it all again to get even stronger!

slides.prompt: Do at least 2 full run-throughs of your capstone presentation. Use the 5-key checklist. After each run, rate yourself on each skill (1-5) and identify one thing to improve for the next round. Practice answering 3 possible questions about your topic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for the big practice run! You'll present your whole report using all five of our presentation powers, and we'll use the checklist to make sure we're doing them. After each time, you'll even get to rate yourself and pick one thing to make even more awesome for the next try. Plus, we'll practice answering some questions, just in case your audience gets super curious about your topic!

slides.text: Encourage: 'You are ready! You know your topic deeply, your report is excellent, and your presentation skills are strong. Next week when you stand in front of your family, remember: you are the EXPERT on this topic. No one knows more about it than you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child present with appropriate volume, eye contact, posture, pacing, and enthusiasm, and can they respond thoughtfully to questions about their topic?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You are totally ready to present your amazing report to your family. You know your topic so well, and you've practiced all the skills to share it powerfully. When you stand up there next week, remember you are the expert, and your excitement will shine through – they're going to be so impressed!

parent_notes: Public speaking is consistently ranked as one of the most important — and most feared — skills in adult life. Teaching it early and positively creates confident communicators. The key is making practice feel safe and supportive, not evaluative. Give genuinely positive specific feedback first ('I loved how you looked right at me when you described the pyramids'), then offer one gentle suggestion ('Next time, try pausing after each big idea to let it sink in'). Never criticize the content or the child's knowledge during presentation practice — that crushes confidence. The physical skills (volume, posture, eye contact) can be practiced separately before combining them. If the child is nervous, normalize it: 'Even professional speakers get nervous. That is your body giving you energy to perform well!' The stuffed animal audience adds humor while making the practice feel real. By the time week 35 arrives, the child should feel prepared and excited, not anxious.

title: Math Review Stations — Fractions, Decimals, and Percentages
description: Students rotate through stations reviewing fractions, decimals, and percentages — concepts that build on each other and connect to real-world applications. Each station includes visual models, computation, and word problems.
instructions:
1. 'Today we celebrate your fraction, decimal, and percentage skills!'
2. Set up 3 stations:
   - Station 1: Fractions — identifying, comparing, equivalent fractions, adding and subtracting with like and unlike denominators, multiplying fractions. Use fraction circles and strips for visual support.
   - Station 2: Decimals — place value, comparing, adding, subtracting, and connecting to money (dollars and cents). Use base-ten blocks for concrete representation.
   - Station 3: Percentages — finding percentages of numbers, converting between fractions/decimals/percentages, real-world discount problems.
3. Each station includes computation problems AND word problems.
4. At each station, the child uses manipulatives first, then solves abstractly, then checks.
5. Self-assessment: star easy problems, circle challenging ones.
6. 'Fractions, decimals, and percentages are three ways of saying the same thing!'

slides.heading: Fractions, Decimals, Percentages
slides.subheading: Three Ways to Say the Same Thing
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the title page of our math adventure! It tells us we're going to be working with fractions, decimals, and percentages, and the super cool thing is that they're all just different ways to talk about the same amount of something. Get ready to become a math whiz who can switch between them like magic!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 3 stations with appropriate manipulatives and problem cards. Station 1 needs fraction materials, Station 2 needs base-ten blocks and play money, Station 3 needs a conversion reference chart. Problems should progress from concrete to abstract at each station.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for this math journey! We've got special fraction circles and strips to help us see parts of a whole, and base-ten blocks that are like building blocks for numbers, especially for decimals. There are also station cards with problems, a calculator to check our work, scratch paper for our brilliant ideas, and stickers to show how awesome we did, plus a conversion chart to help us switch between our math languages. Go grab all these from your grown-up helper so we can get started!

slides.text: Connect the concepts: 'Did you know that 1/2, 0.5, and 50% are all the SAME amount? Fractions, decimals, and percentages are three languages for the same idea. Today you prove you can speak all three!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is all about understanding the big idea: fractions, decimals, and percentages are like three different languages that all mean the same thing! Think about half of a pizza – that's 1/2 as a fraction, 0.5 as a decimal, and 50% as a percentage. Today, you're going to show off how you can speak all three of these math languages!

slides.text: Station 1 — Fractions: 'Use fraction circles to show each fraction, then solve the problems. Compare fractions, find equivalents, and add and subtract. Some problems even ask you to multiply fractions!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Welcome to Station 1, where we're diving deep into fractions! You'll use those cool fraction circles and strips to see what fractions look like, then you'll solve problems about comparing them, finding equal fractions, and even adding and subtracting them. Some problems might even ask you to multiply fractions – that's like finding a part of a part!

slides.text: Station 2 — Decimals: 'Decimals are fractions in disguise! 0.25 is really 25/100 or 1/4. Use base-ten blocks to model decimals, then add and subtract. The money problems use dollars and cents — that is decimals in real life!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for Station 2, where decimals get their moment! Remember how decimals are just fractions with a denominator of 10 or 100? You'll use the base-ten blocks to build decimal numbers, then add and subtract them. And guess what? When we work with money, like dollars and cents, we're actually using decimals in real life!

slides.text: Station 3 — Percentages: 'Percent means per hundred. 25% means 25 out of 100. Find 10% of 80, 50% of 60, 25% of 200. Then try the discount problems — this is the shopping math from last week!'
slides.mascot_explanation: At Station 3, we're talking percentages! "Percent" means "out of one hundred," so you'll figure out things like 10% of a number, which is like taking a small slice. You'll also get to practice changing between fractions, decimals, and percentages, and even tackle discount problems, just like when you're shopping for toys!

slides.prompt: Complete all 3 stations. At each one, start with the manipulatives, then solve problems on paper, then check with a calculator. Include: 4 computation problems and 2 word problems per station. Self-assess with stars and circles.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the action happens! You'll visit all three stations, and at each one, you'll start by using the hands-on tools, then solve the problems on paper, and finally use the calculator to check your amazing answers. Remember to use stars for the problems you found super easy and circles for the ones that made you think a little harder. You've got this!

slides.text: Celebrate connections: 'You just proved you understand fractions, decimals, AND percentages — and you can convert between them! This is sophisticated math that connects to everything from cooking to shopping to science. You are ready for upper elementary math!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child work fluently with fractions, decimals, and percentages, convert between them, and apply these concepts to word problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You just showed off your amazing skills with fractions, decimals, and percentages, and you even learned how to switch between them. That's super advanced math that helps us with everything from baking cookies to understanding sales in stores. You are absolutely ready for all the cool math coming your way in upper elementary school!

parent_notes: The connection between fractions, decimals, and percentages is one of the most important conceptual bridges in elementary mathematics. Many students learn them as separate topics; this review emphasizes their unity. The concrete-to-abstract progression at each station (manipulatives first, then computation, then checking) follows the Montessori principle of moving from hands-on to abstract. If the child struggles with any station, the manipulatives provide a way back to understanding. The conversion between representations (1/4 = 0.25 = 25%) is particularly important for upper elementary readiness. Do not rush this — spend extra time on any station where the child needs it. The real-world problems (money, discounts, cooking measurements) show that these are not just school math but life math. Note which areas are starred and which are circled for summer practice planning.

title: Capstone Experiment — Design and Conduct Your Own Investigation
description: Students design and begin conducting their own original scientific experiment. They apply the full scientific method: observation, question, hypothesis, materials, procedure, data collection, and analysis. This is the capstone science activity demonstrating mastery of scientific thinking.
instructions:
1. 'All year you have been a scientist — observing, experimenting, recording, and analyzing. Today you design your OWN experiment from scratch!'
2. Help the child brainstorm questions they want to investigate. Examples:
   - Does water temperature affect how fast sugar dissolves?
   - Does the color of light affect plant growth?
   - Does the weight of a paper airplane affect how far it flies?
   - Does music affect how fast someone completes a puzzle?
3. Choose one question and formulate a hypothesis: 'I think ___ because ___.'
4. Plan the experiment: identify variables (what you change, what you measure, what stays the same), list materials, write step-by-step procedure.
5. Discuss fair testing: 'Everything must stay the same except the one thing you are testing!'
6. Begin the experiment — collect initial data.
7. Record observations carefully in a data table.
8. 'We will analyze results and write the lab report next time!'
materials_needed: Science journal or lab report template
Measuring tools (ruler, thermometer, timer, scale as needed)

slides.heading: My Own Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big title page for our awesome project! It's called "My Own Experiment," and it means you're going to be the boss of your very own science investigation, just like a real scientist. We've learned so much all year, and now it's your turn to design something super cool to figure out.

slides.setup_instructions: Have multiple experiment options ready with pre-gathered materials. Prepare a lab report template with sections: Question, Hypothesis, Variables, Materials, Procedure, Data Table, Results, Conclusion. Have measuring tools available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the important stuff we'll need to get our experiment rolling. We've got templates for writing down our ideas and results, pencils for writing, and some measuring tools to be super accurate, like rulers or cups. There might also be special things for *your* experiment, like seeds or sugar, and maybe even a camera to take pictures of what happens!

slides.text: Inspire curiosity: 'Every scientific discovery started with someone asking a question and then designing an experiment to find the answer. Today you are that scientist. What do you want to discover?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to the really exciting part – thinking like a scientist! This slide is reminding us that all big discoveries start with a simple question. Think about anything you've ever wondered about, like why things happen or how they work, and we can turn that wonder into a question for your experiment.

slides.text: Choose and hypothesize: 'Pick your question and make a prediction. A good hypothesis explains WHY you think something will happen: I think hot water will dissolve sugar faster BECAUSE heat makes molecules move faster.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next step is where you pick one of those cool questions and make a smart guess about what you think will happen. It's called a hypothesis, and it's not just a guess, it's a guess with a reason! So you'll say what you think will happen, and then explain *why* you think that, like maybe because of something you already know.

slides.text: Plan carefully: 'Identify your variables: the independent variable (what you change), the dependent variable (what you measure), and the controlled variables (everything that stays the same). A fair test changes only ONE thing!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Planning is super important for a fair test, and this slide is all about that. We need to figure out what you're going to change on purpose (that's one variable!), what you're going to measure to see what happens (that's another!), and make sure everything else stays exactly the same so it's a fair comparison.

slides.text: Conduct the experiment: 'Follow your procedure step by step. Measure carefully. Record every observation in your data table. Take pictures if you can. Real scientists are meticulous about recording data!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to do some real science! This step is where you actually *do* your experiment by following the plan you made. You'll be measuring carefully, watching closely, and writing down *everything* you see in your data table, because careful notes help us understand what happened.

slides.prompt: Complete your experiment design (question, hypothesis, variables, materials, procedure) and begin conducting the experiment. Record at least one full trial in your data table. If your experiment needs time (like plant growth), set it up and plan your observation schedule.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event – you get to actually *do* your experiment! Follow all the steps you planned, measure everything precisely, and write down all your observations in the data table. If your experiment takes a few days, like watching a plant grow, just get it set up and make a plan for when you'll check on it.

slides.text: Check in: 'You just designed and began a real scientific experiment! You asked a question, made a prediction, planned a fair test, and collected data. Next session we will analyze your results and write them up. This is exactly what professional scientists do!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child formulate a testable question and hypothesis, identify variables, design a fair experimental procedure, and begin systematic data collection?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You designed and started your very own scientific experiment today, just like a real scientist! You asked a question, made a prediction, planned a fair test, and started collecting your own data. Next time, we'll look at all the cool information you gathered and figure out what it all means!

parent_notes: This is the ultimate test of scientific thinking — not because someone is evaluating the child, but because they are genuinely investigating their own question. The ability to design an experiment from scratch demonstrates deep understanding of the scientific method. Guide the child toward a question that can be tested within one or two sessions with materials you have at home. The variables discussion is critical: many children want to change multiple things at once ('I will use hot water AND more sugar'), which makes results uninterpretable. Help them understand why changing only one variable matters. If the experiment does not go as planned, that is a feature, not a bug — unexpected results are where the best learning happens. Take this experiment seriously: measure carefully, record accurately, and treat the child like a real scientist. Their lab report will be presented at the week 35 science fair. This capstone activity demonstrates the child's readiness for the more independent scientific work of upper elementary.

title: My Year in Art — Portfolio and Reflection
description: Students curate their best artwork from the year into a portfolio, writing artist's statements for their favorite pieces. They reflect on their artistic growth and prepare selected pieces for the week 35 celebration exhibition.
instructions:
1. 'Artists organize their best work into a portfolio — a collection that shows their skills and growth. Today you curate YOUR portfolio!'
2. Spread out all artwork from the year (or as much as can be gathered).
3. Sort into categories: drawing, painting, sculpture/3D, mixed media, crafts.
4. Select 5-8 best pieces that show range and growth.
5. For each selected piece, write an artist's statement: title, date, medium, what it shows, what you are proud of, and what you would change.
6. Arrange pieces in chronological order to show growth over the year.
7. Compare early and late pieces: 'How has your art changed? What new skills did you develop?'
8. Select 2-3 pieces for the week 35 exhibition display.
9. Create a portfolio cover: 'The Art of [child's name] — Year [year].'
materials_needed: Large table for sorting and viewing

slides.heading: My Art Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our awesome art project! It tells us we're going to put together a special collection, called a portfolio, of all the amazing art you've made this year. Think of it like a treasure box for your creativity!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all artwork from the year. If some pieces are in frames or on display, photograph them. Set up a large table or floor space for spreading out and sorting work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our project. We've got your amazing artwork from the whole year, a special folder to keep it all neat, some index cards for writing, pencils and colored pencils for notes, and a big space to spread everything out so we can see it all! We'll need to gather up all your artwork first.

slides.text: Introduce the concept: 'Professional artists keep portfolios of their best work. It shows who they are as an artist and how they have grown. Today you create YOUR artist's portfolio from this entire year of art.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about you becoming a real artist! Just like famous artists have special books or folders to show off their best paintings and sculptures, we're going to make one for you. This portfolio will show everyone how much your art has grown and all the cool things you've learned this year.

slides.text: Sort and select: 'Let us spread out all your art from this year. Look at it all together — that is a LOT of creativity! Now choose your 5 to 8 best pieces. Pick ones that show different skills and ones you are most proud of.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part – picking your favorites! Spread out all the art you've made this year, and let's look at it all together. Choose the 5 to 8 pieces that you think are the absolute best, maybe ones that show different kinds of art you tried or ones you worked really hard on.

slides.text: Write artist's statements: 'For each piece, write on an index card: the title, when you made it, what materials you used, what it represents, and what you like best about it. Professional artists always explain their work.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For each of those special pieces you picked, we're going to write a little story about it on an index card. We'll write down what you called it, when you made it, what you used to make it, what the picture is about, and what part you're most proud of. This is how artists tell people about their amazing creations!

slides.text: Notice growth: 'Put your first piece from the year next to your most recent one. What do you notice? How has your art changed? What new techniques did you learn? This growth is something to celebrate!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at how much your art has changed! Find one of the first things you made this year and put it next to one of your newest pieces. Can you see how your drawings or paintings look different now? Maybe you learned to use new colors or draw things in a cooler way!

slides.prompt: Select your best 5-8 pieces and write artist's statements for each. Arrange them chronologically in your portfolio. Design a portfolio cover with your name and year. Choose 2-3 pieces for the exhibition display next week.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to put everything together! Pick your best 5 to 8 pieces, write those special artist statements for each, and put them in order from the beginning of the year to the end. Then, make a cool cover for your portfolio with your name on it, and choose 2 or 3 pieces to show off at our celebration next week!

slides.text: Celebrate artistry: 'Your portfolio is a record of a year of creative growth. From your earliest pieces to your most recent, you can SEE how your skills, confidence, and artistic voice developed. You are an artist!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child curate work based on quality and variety, write reflective artist's statements, and identify their own artistic growth over time?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! This portfolio shows how much your art skills have grown, like a superhero getting stronger. You can see all the amazing things you've learned and created over the whole year, and that makes you a super talented artist!

parent_notes: Portfolio curation develops metacognitive skills — the child must evaluate their own work, make selections based on quality and variety, and articulate what they value in their art. The artist's statement writing connects art to language arts and develops critical vocabulary. The chronological arrangement makes growth visible: even without explicit instruction, children's art naturally develops in complexity, detail, and expression over a school year. Point out specific improvements: 'Look at how much more detail your drawings have now!' or 'Your color choices have become so sophisticated.' Avoid comparing to other artists or setting external standards — the portfolio reflects this individual child's journey. The exhibition pieces for week 35 should be the ones the child is most proud of, regardless of which ones you think are 'best.' This honors the child's artistic voice and builds confidence in their own aesthetic judgment.

title: Event Planning — Preparing the Year-End Celebration
description: Students plan a real year-end celebration event, applying organizational, mathematical, and social skills. They create invitations, plan the schedule, organize displays of their work, and prepare refreshments — a practical life capstone that combines planning, execution, and hospitality.
instructions:
1. 'Next week is our big celebration — we will share all your amazing work with family! But a great celebration needs great planning. Today YOU are the event planner.'
2. Together, decide: Who will be invited? When will it happen? What will be displayed?
3. Create invitations: include date, time, location, and what guests will experience (history museum, science fair, art exhibition, research presentation, world tour).
4. Plan the schedule: 'We need time for each activity. If we have 2 hours, how should we divide the time?'
5. Plan the display: which projects go where? How will the room be set up?
6. Plan refreshments: simple snacks the child can help prepare. Calculate quantities based on number of guests.
7. Create a task list with deadlines: what needs to be done before the celebration?
8. 'You are managing a real event — logistics, communication, hospitality, and organization!'
materials_needed: Room layout paper for display planning

slides.heading: Party Planning!
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the big title for our fun project! It says "Party Planning!" and tells us we're going to organize our very own year-end celebration, where we get to show off all the cool things we've learned and made. It’s exciting because we get to be the boss of the party!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare templates for: invitation design, event schedule, room layout sketch, and task checklist with deadlines. Have a calendar available for selecting the celebration date.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we'll need to be amazing party planners! We've got materials for making invitations, a special paper to help us plan the whole event, another paper for drawing how we want the room to look, a paper for making a schedule, and even a calculator to help with numbers. We need all these things to make sure our celebration is super organized and fun for everyone.

slides.text: Set the vision: 'Next week we celebrate everything you accomplished this year! You will present your research, show your art, share your atlas page, display your experiments, and more. But first — we need to PLAN this event.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start being the chief party planner! Our year-end celebration is happening next week, and it's a chance to share everything you've done, like your awesome research, creative art, interesting history timelines, and cool science experiments. But before the party fun, we need to plan it all out, just like a real event organizer would!

slides.text: Create invitations: 'Who should come? Grandparents, family friends, siblings? Make beautiful invitations with all the important details: date, time, place, and what guests will see. Make them excited to come!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to think about who we want to invite to our celebration – maybe family, friends, or even special guests! We'll get to make beautiful invitations that tell everyone when the party is, what time it starts, where it will be, and all the exciting things they'll get to see and do. Making these invitations is like sending out a special secret message to get everyone excited!

slides.text: Plan the schedule: 'If the celebration is 2 hours long, we need to fit in: research presentations, science fair, art exhibition, history timeline tour, world tour, and refreshments. How long for each? Let us create a schedule.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about making a plan for the party's timing. If our celebration is two hours long, we need to figure out how much time to spend on each special activity, like sharing our research, looking at the art, or exploring the history timeline. We'll work together to make a schedule so we know exactly what's happening and when, making sure there's enough time for everything.

slides.text: Plan the space and food: 'Sketch the room layout — where will the timeline go? The art? The science display? Then plan the refreshments. If 8 people are coming and each person gets 3 cookies, how many cookies do we need?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we get to be designers and chefs! First, we'll draw a map of the room to decide where all our amazing projects will go, like where the science fair will be or where the art will hang. Then, we'll plan the yummy snacks and figure out exactly how many cookies or drinks we need based on how many guests are coming, just like a real caterer!

slides.prompt: Complete your event plan: (1) Create at least 3 invitations, (2) Write a schedule with time blocks, (3) Sketch the room layout for displays, (4) Calculate refreshment quantities, (5) Make a task checklist with deadlines. This is YOUR event!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your big chance to put everything together and plan the whole celebration! You'll create at least three invitations, write out a schedule with times for each activity, draw how the room will look, figure out how much food you need, and make a list of all the things that need to be done before the party. You are the main event planner, and you've got this!

slides.text: Review the plan: 'You just planned an entire event — invitations, schedule, layout, food, and logistics. This takes the same skills as planning a business meeting, a conference, or a wedding! You are ready to host your celebration.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child plan an event with invitations, schedule, spatial layout, quantity calculations, and a task management checklist?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've just done! You've planned out an entire celebration, from the invitations and schedule to the room layout and food, and even made a list of tasks. This shows you have super important skills that grown-ups use for planning big events like parties, meetings, or even weddings! You're ready to host an amazing celebration!

parent_notes: Event planning is one of the most complex practical life activities because it integrates so many skills: communication (invitations), mathematics (time blocking, quantity calculations), spatial reasoning (room layout), executive function (task management, deadlines), and social awareness (hospitality, anticipating guest needs). The child should make real decisions and do real work — this is not a pretend exercise. Actually send the invitations, follow the schedule, and prepare the refreshments together. The task checklist teaches project management — breaking a complex goal into specific, time-bound steps. If the child forgets something in the plan, let them discover it rather than pointing it out preemptively; discovering gaps and solving them is the learning. This activity transforms the child from passive recipient of a celebration into its active creator, which is deeply empowering and perfectly Montessori.

title: Literary Magazine — Compiling the Year's Best Writing
description: Students select, revise, and compile their best writing from the year into a personal literary magazine. They learn about editing for publication, designing layouts, and creating a table of contents — producing a tangible record of their growth as writers.
instructions:
1. 'Published authors choose their best work to share with the world. Today you create YOUR literary magazine — a collection of your finest writing from the whole year!'
2. Gather all writing from the year: stories, poems, research papers, letters, journal entries, essays.
3. Select 6-10 pieces that represent the child's best work across different genres.
4. For each piece, do a quick revision pass: fix any errors, improve word choices, clean up formatting.
5. Create a table of contents listing each piece with its page number and genre.
6. Design a cover: title (e.g., 'Words and Wonders: A Literary Magazine by [Name]'), illustration, year.
7. Write an 'About the Author' page with a brief biography and photo or self-portrait.
8. Assemble in order, number pages, bind or staple.
9. 'You are a published author! This magazine showcases a year of growth!'
materials_needed: Colored pencils for cover and illustrations

slides.heading: My Literary Magazine
slides.subheading: A Year of Writing in One Collection
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page of a super special book we're making together! It's called "My Literary Magazine," and it's going to hold all the amazing writing you've done this whole school year. Think of it as a treasure chest for your words!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all the child's writing from the year. Sort by genre (story, poem, essay, letter, research, journal) and by date. Have clean paper available for any pieces that need fresh copies.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, we need a few things to make our magazines. First, we need all the writing you've done this year – like stories, poems, or even letters you've written. Then, grab some clean paper, colored pencils for decorating, a stapler or binder to hold it all together, and a special paper called a table of contents template. You'll also need your pencils for writing!

slides.text: Set the vision: 'Literary magazines publish the best writing of their authors. Today you are both the author AND the editor of YOUR magazine. You get to choose what goes in and how it looks.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like being the boss of your own amazing book! You get to decide exactly what goes into your magazine because you're both the writer and the editor. This means you choose your very best work to share with everyone, just like famous authors do.

slides.text: Curate carefully: 'Look through all your writing. Which pieces are you most proud of? Which ones show different skills — a powerful story, a beautiful poem, a well-researched report, a persuasive letter? Choose 6 to 10 of your best.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part – picking your favorite writing! Look through everything you've written this year. Which stories made you feel excited? Which poems sound beautiful? Which reports taught you something new? Choose about 6 to 10 pieces that show off all the different ways you're a fantastic writer.

slides.text: Edit for publication: 'Before publishing, editors check every piece one more time. Read each selection aloud. Fix any spelling errors. Improve any words that could be stronger. Make sure every piece is your BEST version.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like being a super-detective for your words! Before we put your writing in the magazine, we need to make sure it's perfect. Read each piece out loud to catch any sneaky spelling mistakes and think about if you can use even cooler words to make your writing extra special. We want every single piece to be the absolute best it can be!

slides.text: Design and assemble: 'Create a cover that is worthy of a real magazine. Write a table of contents. Add an About the Author page with your biography. Assemble everything in order and bind it together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to make your magazine look super professional! You'll design a cool cover with a title and maybe a drawing, create a list at the beginning that tells people what's inside and what page it's on, and write a little bit about yourself, like a mini-biography. Then, we'll put all the pages together in order.

slides.prompt: Select your pieces, do final edits, create the table of contents, design the cover, write your About the Author page, and assemble the literary magazine. Include at least 3 different genres of writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put it all together! You'll pick your best 6-10 pieces, do one last check to make them perfect, create that table of contents, design a cover that pops, write your "About the Author" page, and then assemble everything. Make sure you have at least three different kinds of writing in there, like a story, a poem, and an essay!

slides.text: Celebrate publication: 'You are holding a REAL literary magazine — YOUR words, YOUR voice, YOUR growth as a writer, all in one beautiful collection. From the first things you wrote this year to the most recent, you can see how much your writing has grown. You are a published author!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child select quality writing across genres, edit for publication, create organizational elements (table of contents, cover), and assemble a cohesive literary collection?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've made! You are officially a published author with your very own literary magazine. This book shows how much your writing has grown and changed all year long, from the first words you wrote to the amazing pieces you just finished. You should be so proud of yourself!

parent_notes: The literary magazine is one of the most meaningful end-of-year activities because it makes the child's writing journey visible and permanent. Selecting pieces across genres demonstrates range; comparing early and late pieces reveals growth. The editing-for-publication process teaches that published work goes through multiple revisions — an important lesson for a culture that often values first drafts and instant posting. The About the Author page is delightful and builds identity: the child writes about themselves as a writer, which reinforces that they ARE a writer. Consider making copies of the magazine for grandparents or other family members — having real readers makes the publishing process feel authentic. This magazine can be shared at the week 35 celebration. It becomes a cherished keepsake — years from now, the family will treasure this window into the child's mind at this age.

title: Math Review Stations — Geometry and Measurement
description: Students rotate through stations reviewing geometric concepts (shapes, angles, area, perimeter, symmetry) and measurement (length, mass, volume, time, temperature). Each station combines identification, calculation, and application problems.
instructions:
1. 'Today we celebrate your geometry and measurement mastery!'
2. Set up 4 stations:
   - Station 1: Shapes and Angles — identify and classify triangles (equilateral, isosceles, scalene, right, acute, obtuse), quadrilaterals (square, rectangle, rhombus, parallelogram, trapezoid), and other polygons. Measure angles with a protractor.
   - Station 2: Area and Perimeter — calculate area and perimeter of rectangles, triangles, and composite shapes. Word problems involving real-world measurements.
   - Station 3: Symmetry and Transformations — identify lines of symmetry, complete symmetric drawings, identify reflections and rotations.
   - Station 4: Measurement — convert between units (cm/m, g/kg, mL/L), measure real objects, solve measurement word problems including time and temperature.
3. Each station: 3-4 problems with manipulatives available.
4. Self-assessment at each station.
